titlestmt.titleproper: Finding aid for the Betty Millard papers SSC.MS.00673
titlestmt.author: Kate Sumner, Amanda Ferrara, Madison White, Isabel Montesanto, and Sky Karp

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2019-05-03 16:16:21 -0400.

change.item: This record was migrated from InMagic DB Textworks to ArchivesSpace.
This record was edited by Amanda Ferrara.

did.abstract: Betty Millard was a writer, political and labor activist, and photographer. She was involved in Communism and Marxism and was interested in global social justice. Millard was the author of Woman Against Myth, a key feminist seminal that examined the history of the women's movement in the United States, in the socialist movement, and in the USSR. The papers document Millard's personal and professional life. It includes writings and photos by, about, and collected by Millard, paper records of Millard's travels, and personal journals from the entirety of her life, some which document her personal exploration of, and struggle with, her sexuality.
did.langmaterial: The materials in the collection are mostly in English. Some materials are in French, Spanish, Russian, Chinese and Japanese.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for use without restriction beyond the standard terms and conditions of Smith College Special Collections.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The Betty Millard papers were donated to the Sophia Smith Collection by her estate executors - her niece, Olivia Millard, and her close friend, Lisa Springer, in two accessions in 2011 and 2013.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p:
The materials are organized into five series:
Biographical
Correspondence
Professional
Writings
Photographs

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Elizabeth (Betty) Boynton Millard was born on October 12, 1911. She was born to a wealthy, conservative family in Highland Park, Illinois and lived there until she attended college. Her mother, Elizabeth (Bessie) Bell Boynton (1882-1980) was a Smith College student from 1900-1902 and studied painting, sculpture, and music. She became an artist. Her father, Everett Lee Millard (1877-1933) was an attorney. Betty was the second of four children; younger to Everett Lee (Chevy) Millard, Jr. (1909-2000); older to Malcolm (Mac) S. Millard (1914-1999), and Graham Millard (1921-1921). Malcolm's first wife, Margaret Wentworth Owings, whose work focused on endangered species conservation, was a life-long friend to Betty Millard. Betty Millard remained close to her brother Malcolm throughout her life, despite their significant political and lifestyle differences. Her closest familial relationship for the latter half of her life was with her niece Olivia Millard, with whom she shared a love of nature, travel and conservation.

Millard first attended the University of Chicago from 1930-1932, but transferred to Barnard College in 1932. She briefly studied at the University of London and in Vienna during her college years. Her interest in political activism and social justice flourished during this time period and directed her professional interests for the continuation of her life. Millard was drawn to the on-campus activism at Barnard College, and marched against the U.S. government's support of Francisco Franco in the Spanish Civil War. She graduated from Barnard College in 1934 and enrolled at Columbia Law School, but left after one year in order to pursue her activism. In exploring her preferred ideals of equality and fairness, Betty joined the Young Communist League in 1936 and the Communist party in 1940. In 1935, she moved to Greenwich Village, where she was based for the rest of her life.

From 1943-1947, Betty Millard worked as an editor and writer at The New Masses, a publication focused on American Marxism. In 1947, during her time at The New Masses, Betty wrote the widely acclaimed, key feminist seminal, Woman Against Myth. It was published as a 24-page pamphlet in 1948 distributed with the magazine and was released by International later that year.Woman Against Myth examined the history of the women's movement in the United States, in the socialist movement, and in the USSR.

From 1949-1951, Betty Millard worked in Paris, France and Berlin, Germany as the American Secretary in the directorate of the Women's International Democratic Federation (WIDF). The WIDF was a post-war, radical feminist organization that aligned with the global Communist movement. Millard was also active in the Congress of American Women (CAW), an affiliate of WIDF. Her work for both organizations took her to France, Italy, the Soviet Union, Poland, Hungary, China, Finland, Denmark, Switzerland, and Germany. When she returned to the United States in 1951, her passport was lifted due to suspected Communist affiliation.

From 1951-1956, Betty Millard worked as an editor and writer at the magazine Latin America Today, reporting on the political and social developments south of the United States border. In April 1959, Millard was subpoenaed to testify as a hostile witness before the House of Un-American Activities Committee during the McCarthy trials. The House was investigating the Congress of American Women, Millard's work for them, as well as her personal political views. Millard left the Communist Party in the late 1950's â€“ possibly as a result of the Khrushchev revelations, or possibly out of dissatisfaction with the Party's hostile viewpoints on feminism, women's rights and gay rights.

In 1960, Millard developed a passion for photography and installed a darkroom on the top floor of her Greenwich Village brownstone. Millard studied photography with Paul Caponigro, Lisa Modell, and Ansel Adams. She was interested in photography of nature, political struggles, and portraiture. Millard created "picture stories" while travelling including on trips up the Essequibo and Pomeroon Rivers in then-British Guiana; visiting the artist, David Alfaro Siqueiros, at work in his studio; and to Chile in 1970 to photograph Chilean mural art.

Betty Millard spent the remainder of her life travelling to various parts of the world, often in service of advocacy. Betty Millard supported many activist organizations, especially in Latin America. She worked on campaigns such as organizing a committee to free the Mexican muralist, David Siqueiros, from prison, movements that were against the Vietnam War, environmentalism, and later in her life, she joined the fight for lesbian and gay rights. Millard was also a philanthropist and supported various activist groups, including the North Star Fund, which worked to create a more equitable and democratic city for all New Yorkers. She attended the March on Washington in 1963.

Millard met, interviewed, and befriended a variety of political figures throughout her life including artists David Siqueiros and Diego Rivera, W. E. B. Du Bois, Ho Chi Minh, Zhou Enlai, Fidel Castro, Marie-Claude Vaillant-Couturier, Cheddi and Janet Jagan, Paul and Eslanda Robeson, Elizabeth Moos, and Bella Abzug. Millard and Janet Jagan met while they both attended the University of Chicago. Millard would continue to be close friends with the Jagans for the remainder of their lives.

Millard traveled through British Guiana with politician Cheddi Jagan as he campaigned for Chief Minister, and later, Premier. She spoke alongside Jagan at an event in New York City shortly after he was elected President of independent Guyana on December 5, 1992. In this, her last public speaking appearance, she eloquently compared Jagan's early campaign-trail appeal to that of the recently-elected U.S. President, Bill Clinton.

Despite privately writing about her struggles with her sexual orientation in journals, Millard did not come out as gay until her late 80s except to close family and friends. Millard often referenced her crushes on schoolmates in her journals and described her younger self as bisexual. Due to the social implications of being gay and the explicit homophobia of the Communist Party, Millard took measures to reject this part of her life by seeking conversion therapy from 1942-1948; she was hospitalized in 1956 for a breakdown related to her struggles with her sexuality. Despite this, Millard had several important long-term relationships with women prior to, and after, coming out.

Millard enjoyed writing short stories and poetry, most of which were autobiographical. Some of Millard's writing was anthologized, and others can be found in The Guardian. In 1960, Millard purchased a small farm in Dutchess County, upstate New York and regularly spent time there.
Millard passed away on March 6, 2010 at her home in New York City, New York.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: As a preservation measure, researchers must use digital reproductions of the audiovisual materials in this collection. Access to audiovisual materials requires the creation of digital access copies. Please consult with Special Collections staff to request digitization of and access to materials.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Betty Millard papers, Sophia Smith Collection, SSC-MS-00673, Smith College Special Collections, Northampton, Massachusetts.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The Betty Millard papers were accessioned by Kathleen Banks Nutter in 2011 and 2013, and processed by Kate Sumner in 2016 and Amanda Ferrara in 2017. Some parts of the collection had inherent structure and some did not. For the parts that had structure, the structure was left intact. For the parts that did not have structure, structure was created by the processing archivists. Appraisal was conducted in accordance with the Sophia Smith Collections' guidelines and policies. Very few duplicate items were returned to the donor.

The papers were re-examined by Isabel Montesanto and Sky Karp (under the direction of Madison White) in 2019. Portions of the collection were reboxed to eliminate excess space, and the materials in the "Collected by" subseries in series IV, which had simply been alphabetized, were grouped by topic. Series V was re-examined and renamed, given a more detailed scope and contents note and folders were labeled by roll number and subject matter to increase accessibility for the researcher. The new arrangement of series IV and information about and organization of series V was added to the finding aid.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p:
Related materials may be found in the following collections at Smith College Special Collections:
MS 452, Communism, Socialism, and Left-Wing Politics Collection
MS 594, Women's International Democratic Federation (WIDF) Records
MS 482, Miscellaneous Organizations Collection

Additional WIDF materials can be found in the Sophia Smith Collection in the papers of
MS 300, Mary Metlay Kaufman
MS 85, Dorothy Kenyon
MS 165, Mary van Kleeck
MS 175, Ruth Frances Woodsmall
WIDF's magazine Women of the Whole World is located with the MS 537,Sophia Smith Collection Periodicals Collection

Betty Millard's mother, Elizabeth (Bessie) Bell Boynton (1882-1980) was a Smith College student from 1900-1902 and studied painting, sculpture, and music. Materials can be found within the Smith College Archives.
The Margaret Owings Collection resides at the Bancroft Library.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Betty Millard papers relate to both her personal and professional life. Especially well documented are: Millard's research and writings; her travels; her correspondence with notable politicians and communist activists; and her photography, including travel, artistic, and personal photos. The collection includes clippings, memoribilia, journals, articles, correspondence, personal and collected writings, and photography.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: To the extent that she owns copyright, Olivia Millard has assigned the copyright in her aunt's works to Smith College; however, copyright in other items in this collection may be held by their respective creators. For reproductions of materials that are governed by fair use as defined under U. S. Copyright Law, no permission to cite or publish is required. For instances which may regard materials in the collection not created by Betty Millard, researchers are responsible for determining who may hold materials' copyrights and obtaining approval from them. Researchers do not need anything further from Smith College Special Collections to move forward with their use.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Biographical Materials series contains biographical information about Millard's personal life. It includes address books, biographies/autobiographies, clippings, journals, memorabilia, and information about her early childhood years and education. The journals are from early to late in her life, are very detailed, and include information on her education (with sketches and class notes), travelling (with maps, journaling, and notes), personal journals, and journals on her gardening (with maps, sketches, and notes). Memorabilia includes United Nations membership cards, passports, and collected buttons. Autobiographies include detailed lists of trips with friends, companions, and various jobs she had.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Correspondence series is arranged first by subject and then chronologically. Some notable correspondents include Cheddi and Janet Jagan, Marie-Claude Vaillant-Couturier, and W.E.B. Du Bois. There is correspondence from her time at the organizations she worked at. Much of the chronological correspondence contains letters between Millard and her family members. Millard's original subpoena from Congress to testify to the Committee on Un-American Activities on April 21, 1959 is included in the 1951-1959 correspondence.

did.unittitle: To Betty Millard at New Masses

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Professional Records series is organized into three categories: Administrative, Subjects, and Research. Notable folders include Millard's activist work in the Artists Committee for Siqueiros organization, research for her writings, transcript and notes from her interview with Diego Rivera, and copies of newsletters and pamphlets from various news outlets and organizations she worked for.

did.unittitle: Research: Budapest, Second Women's International Congress
Research: Congress of American Women (CAW)-Statue of Women Commission (St of W C)
Research: Old Congress of American Women (CAW) writing
Research: Women, Wide - articles, etc. by Betty Millard
Research: Charles St. for Peace Organizing
Research: FWI + FG, Fr. in Amer. - Gene
Research: Millard's friends and interests, organizing
Research: Ideas for Latin America articles

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Writings series is organized into two categories: writings by Millard and writings collected by her. Millard's writings include drafts and final copies of her pamphlet Women Against Myth, released in 1948 while employed at the publication New Masses; Women On Guard, released in 1948, poetry, short stories, and fiction. Millard's collected writings include "people's" music scores and lyrics, Marxist periodicals and pamphlets on a variety of Marxist issues, materials on American race relations, feminist press materials, pamphlets and literature related to people's movements worldwide (China, Cuba, Guyana and the USSR are most heavily represented), and records from events such as Congressional hearings on communism.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains drafts and published writings by Millard, including her 1948 "Woman Against Myth" pamphlet.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: From the "Collected by" subseries in Series IV, removed duplicate materials, widely available materials not authored/obviously used by Millard and/or unrelated to collection scope.
A list of removed materials is available on request.

did.unittitle: Race relations in the USA (books, pamphlets, poetry)

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p:
The Photographs Series is organized into four sub-series:
Negatives
Slides
Prints
Photograms

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Photography Materials series is arranged into four sub-series: Negatives, Slides, Photographs, and Photograms. The series includes photographs of Millard's travels, political activities, portraits of family and friends and landscapes, as well as her notes and captions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The negatives sub-series contains negatives of Millard's travels, protests and peace marches, portraits of family, friends and colleagues, landscapes and art photography. Note that this series contains many of the same photos in the prints sub-series; researchers can use the roll number to match them. Negatives in this series are mainly in the format of slides and Bower files. This category also includes internegatives and notebooks with Millard's notes on rolls (see Box 47).

did.unittitle: Women Strike for Peace (WSP) Demonstration, Roll 11
Casino de la Selva, Cuernavaca, Roll 170
Bellas Artes, Hospital de la Raza, Electricidad; Roll 228
Pere Lachaise, Paris and Venice; Roll 463

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The prints sub-series contains photos documenting Millard's travels to South America, Europe, the USSR, Haiti, and Guyana; her political activities and protests, including the Vietnam anti-war movement, the People's Progressive Party, the March on Washington, Gay Pride and organization meetings; and portraits of colleagues and friends, cats, family and school pictures. This category also includes pictures of art and pottery, landscapes, nature and wildlife, as well as art photography. Additionally, researchers can find pictures of Millard herself, often with Cheddi Jagan. While this category is mostly photographs, it also includes related correspondence, newspaper and magazine clippings, comics, cards, art and posters. Boxes 67-71 (oversized) contains larger prints (many of which are duplicates of other photos in the collection), and mounted and framed photos, as well as photo collages, including some negatives. This category contains many copies of the same photo; researchers can see Millard experimenting with light, size, print and color, as well as Millard's notes and descriptions of some of the photos. For more negatives, see the negatives sub-series, and for slides, see the slides sub-series.

did.unittitle: Photos of Elizabeth Moos and Others
School pictures, Other Miscellaneous Photos, Rolls 10 and 322
